levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising that a sentence is a group of words that makes sense on its own, not just a single word.
levels.example_task: Which is a sentence: 'The cat sat on the mat' or 'cat mat sat'?
levels.example_response: 'The cat sat on the mat' is a sentence because it makes sense. 'Cat mat sat' doesn't make sense.
common_errors: Thinking any group of words is a sentence
Not understanding what 'makes sense' means in this context

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying where sentences begin and end when reading, and beginning to use capitals and full stops in own writing.
levels.example_task: This passage has no capital letters or full stops. Read it and add them in: 'the sun was shining the children played outside they had fun'
levels.example_response: 'The sun was shining. The children played outside. They had fun.'
common_errors: Putting a full stop after every line rather than at the end of each sentence
Correctly identifying one boundary but not others

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Consistently demarcating sentences with capital letters and appropriate end punctuation in own writing.
levels.example_task: Write four sentences about the weather today. Make sure every sentence starts with a capital and ends with the right punctuation mark.
levels.example_response: Child writes four sentences, each starting with a capital letter and ending with a full stop, question mark or exclamation mark as appropriate.
common_errors: Demarcating the first sentence but losing consistency in later sentences
Using 'and' to join everything into one long sentence without boundaries

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining how sentence boundaries affect meaning and reading, and varying sentence length for effect.
levels.example_task: Read these two versions aloud. Which is easier to understand and why? Version A: 'The dog ran it was fast the boy chased it.' Version B: 'The dog ran. It was fast. The boy chased it.'
levels.example_response: 'Version B is easier because the full stops tell you where to pause. In Version A you can't tell where one idea ends and the next begins. The full stops help the reader understand the meaning.'
common_errors: Preferring Version B but not being able to explain why
Not connecting sentence boundaries to reader comprehension

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising that the first word of a sentence needs a capital letter when shown examples.
levels.example_task: Look at this sentence: 'the dog barked.' What's wrong? How do we fix it?
levels.example_response: 'It needs a capital T at the beginning. It should be "The dog barked."'
common_errors: Not noticing that the capital is missing
Knowing the rule but not being able to identify the error

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using capital letters at the start of most sentences in own writing.
levels.example_task: Write three sentences about your favourite food. Start each one with a capital letter.
levels.example_response: Child writes three sentences, each beginning with a capital letter.
common_errors: Capitalising the first sentence but forgetting for the second and third
Using a lower-case letter after a full stop because the focus is on the new content

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Consistently using capital letters at the start of every sentence in independent writing.
levels.example_task: Write a paragraph about your weekend. Every sentence must start with a capital letter.
levels.example_response: Child writes a paragraph with capital letters consistently at every sentence start.
common_errors: Maintaining capitals for most sentences but missing one or two, especially mid-paragraph
Using capitals at sentence starts but also capitalising random words mid-sentence

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using capital letters accurately in all contexts — sentence starts, proper nouns and 'I' — with no errors in extended writing.
levels.example_task: Write a recount of your school trip. Use capitals correctly everywhere they are needed — and only where they are needed.
levels.example_response: Child uses capitals correctly for sentence starts, names, places, days and 'I', with no unnecessary capitalisation.
common_errors: Capitalising common nouns that feel important (e.g., 'we saw the Lions')
Forgetting to capitalise 'I' when it appears mid-sentence

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Placing a full stop at the end of a sentence when reminded by the teacher.
levels.example_task: You've written your sentence. What do we need at the end? Add it.
levels.example_response: Child adds a full stop at the end of the sentence.
common_errors: Needing a reminder every time rather than remembering independently
Placing the full stop after every line of writing rather than at the end of each sentence

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using full stops at the end of most sentences in own writing without reminders.
levels.example_task: Write three sentences about animals. Remember to use a full stop after each one.
levels.example_response: Child writes three sentences, each ending with a full stop.
common_errors: Placing a full stop after the first sentence but forgetting for later ones
Using a full stop after a phrase or fragment rather than a complete sentence

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using full stops consistently to end statements in independent writing.
levels.example_task: Write a paragraph about your hobby. Use full stops to end every statement.
levels.example_response: Child uses full stops correctly after every statement, distinguishing from questions or exclamations.
common_errors: Using full stops for all sentence types, including questions
Omitting full stops when concentrating on the content of writing

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Choosing accurately between full stops, question marks and exclamation marks for sentence endings.
levels.example_task: Write four sentences about a surprise party: one statement, one question, one exclamation, and one command. Use the right punctuation for each.
levels.example_response: 'Everyone hid behind the sofa. Would he notice the decorations? What a wonderful surprise it was! Be quiet and don't move.'
common_errors: Using the correct punctuation for three types but confusing exclamations and statements
Adding a full stop after the exclamation mark

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising that a question asks something and ends with a special mark, different from a full stop.
levels.example_task: Is this a question or a telling sentence: 'Where is the cat?' Point to the special mark at the end.
levels.example_response: 'It's a question because it asks something. That curly mark at the end is a question mark.'
common_errors: Not distinguishing between questions and statements
Pointing to the question mark but calling it a full stop

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using question marks when writing questions using question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
levels.example_task: Write two questions you would like to ask a zookeeper. Use question marks.
levels.example_response: 'What do the lions eat? How often do you clean the enclosures?'
common_errors: Writing a question but ending it with a full stop
Writing a statement disguised as a question ('I want to know what they eat.')

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using question marks accurately and consistently in independent writing whenever a question is written.
levels.example_task: Write a passage that includes at least two questions and two statements. Punctuate each correctly.
levels.example_response: 'We went to the park. Have you ever been there? The slide was enormous. Did you know it was the tallest in the town?'
common_errors: Using question marks for sentences that are not questions ('I wondered what it was?')
Consistently forgetting question marks even when the sentence clearly asks something

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Distinguishing between direct questions requiring question marks and indirect questions that do not.
levels.example_task: Which of these needs a question mark: 'She asked where the book was' or 'Where is the book'? Explain why.
levels.example_response: '"Where is the book?" needs a question mark because it directly asks a question. "She asked where the book was." doesn't need one because it's telling you about a question — it's a statement about what she asked.'
common_errors: Putting question marks on both because both contain the word 'where'
Not understanding the difference between direct and reported questions

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising that exclamation marks show strong feeling, and reading exclamatory sentences with expression.
levels.example_task: Read these two sentences: 'It is hot.' and 'It is so hot!' What is different about how they sound?
levels.example_response: 'The second one sounds more excited or surprised. The mark at the end means you say it with more feeling.'
common_errors: Reading both sentences in the same tone
Not connecting the exclamation mark to a change in expression

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using exclamation marks in own writing for sentences showing strong feelings.
levels.example_task: Write a sentence showing surprise: something that made you say 'Wow!'
levels.example_response: 'What an amazing trick that was!'
common_errors: Putting an exclamation mark after a statement that doesn't show strong feeling
Using multiple exclamation marks (!!!) for extra emphasis

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using exclamation marks appropriately for exclamations and commands, not overusing them.
levels.example_task: Write one exclamation starting with 'What' or 'How', and one command. Use exclamation marks correctly.
levels.example_response: 'What a beautiful sunset! Stop running in the corridor!'
common_errors: Using exclamation marks after ordinary statements
Not knowing that exclamation sentences begin with 'What' or 'How'

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the grammatical form of an exclamation sentence and choosing deliberately between full stops, question marks and exclamation marks for effect.
levels.example_task: What makes 'What a great day!' an exclamation sentence? Why not just write 'It was a great day.'?
levels.example_response: '"What a great day!" is an exclamation because it starts with "What", contains a verb (even though it's hidden: "it was") and expresses strong feeling. "It was a great day." is just a statement — it tells you the information but doesn't sound excited.'
common_errors: Thinking any sentence ending in '!' is an exclamation sentence
Not understanding the specific grammatical structure required

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Writing own name with a capital letter and understanding that names start with capitals.
levels.example_task: Write your name. What kind of letter does it start with?
levels.example_response: Child writes 'Emily' with a capital E. 'It starts with a capital letter because it's my name.'
common_errors: Writing name in all lower case
Not understanding why names need capital letters

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using capitals for people's names, days of the week and the pronoun 'I' in own writing.
levels.example_task: Write a sentence about what you did with a friend on a particular day. Use capital letters for the name and the day.
levels.example_response: 'On Monday I played with Sarah at lunchtime.'
common_errors: Capitalising the friend's name but not the day of the week
Writing 'i' in lower case

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Consistently using capitals for proper nouns (names, places, days) and 'I' in independent writing.
levels.example_task: Write about a character who visits London on Saturday with their friend. Use capitals wherever they are needed.
levels.example_response: 'On Saturday, Tom and I went to London. We visited Buckingham Palace and the Tower of London.'
common_errors: Capitalising character names but not place names
Forgetting capitals for 'I' mid-sentence

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Distinguishing between proper and common nouns and explaining why capitals are used for one but not the other.
levels.example_task: Why does 'London' have a capital letter but 'city' does not? Explain the rule.
levels.example_response: 'London is a proper noun — it's the name of one specific place. City is a common noun — it could be any city. Proper nouns name a specific person, place or thing and always have a capital letter.'
common_errors: Knowing the rule but not being able to explain it clearly
Capitalising common nouns that feel important (e.g., 'Dog', 'School')

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using 'and' to join two words in a list.
levels.example_task: What did you have for lunch? Put 'and' between the things you ate.
levels.example_response: 'I had a sandwich and an apple.'
common_errors: Listing items without 'and' ('sandwich, apple')
Using 'and' at the start of the sentence instead of within it

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using 'and' to join two clauses within a sentence.
levels.example_task: Join these two sentences using 'and': 'The dog barked.' 'The cat ran away.'
levels.example_response: 'The dog barked and the cat ran away.'
common_errors: Writing both sentences separately with 'and' starting the second: 'The dog barked. And the cat ran away.'
Using 'and' but not creating a grammatically complete combined sentence

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using 'and' appropriately in writing, alongside other conjunctions (but, or, so), without overusing it.
levels.example_task: Write three sentences about a day at the beach. Use 'and' in one, 'but' in another, and 'so' in the third.
levels.example_response: 'We built a sandcastle and dug a moat. The water was cold but we still went swimming. It started to rain so we packed up and went home.'
common_errors: Using 'and' in all three sentences despite the instruction
Using the conjunction incorrectly (e.g., 'The water was cold so we went swimming')

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Recognising when a sentence is overloaded with 'and' and splitting it into shorter sentences for clarity.
levels.example_task: Improve this sentence by splitting it up: 'We went to the shop and bought milk and bread and cheese and then we went home and mum made sandwiches and we ate them in the garden.'
levels.example_response: 'We went to the shop and bought milk, bread and cheese. Then we went home. Mum made sandwiches so we ate them in the garden.'
common_errors: Splitting into too many very short sentences that lose flow
Not replacing some 'ands' with other conjunctions or punctuation

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Distinguishing between a question and a statement (asking vs telling).
levels.example_task: Which sentence is asking and which is telling? 'The cat is black.' 'Is the cat black?'
levels.example_response: '"The cat is black" is telling. "Is the cat black?" is asking.'
common_errors: Not hearing the difference in intonation between a question and a statement
Thinking any sentence with a question word is a question

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying all four sentence types (statement, question, exclamation, command) in texts.
levels.example_task: Sort these sentences: 'Close the door.' 'What a cold day!' 'Is it snowing?' 'It is winter.'
levels.example_response: Command: 'Close the door.' Exclamation: 'What a cold day!' Question: 'Is it snowing?' Statement: 'It is winter.'
common_errors: Confusing commands with statements
Identifying exclamations as statements because they contain factual information

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Writing all four sentence types with correct punctuation, understanding their different purposes.
levels.example_task: Write one of each sentence type about school: a statement, a question, an exclamation and a command.
levels.example_response: 'School starts at nine o'clock. When is the school play? What an amazing assembly that was! Listen carefully to the teacher.'
common_errors: Writing a statement with an exclamation mark and calling it an exclamation
Writing a question without question word order ('You like school?')

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Choosing sentence types for effect in writing and explaining why different types suit different purposes.
levels.example_task: You are writing about a fire drill. Which sentence types would you use and why?
levels.example_response: 'Commands: "Line up quickly. Walk to the assembly point." These tell people what to do in an emergency. A statement for information: "The alarm will ring at 10 o'clock." An exclamation to show urgency: "What a loud alarm that was!"'
common_errors: Choosing appropriate types but not explaining the reasoning
Defaulting to statements for everything

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding a single adjective before a noun to describe it.
levels.example_task: Describe the dog. Add a word before 'dog' to tell me more about it: 'The ___ dog.'
levels.example_response: 'The big dog.'
common_errors: Adding a verb instead of an adjective ('The running dog')
Choosing a vague adjective ('The nice dog')

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using two adjectives before a noun, separated by a comma, to create an expanded noun phrase.
levels.example_task: Expand the noun phrase: 'the castle' — add two adjectives to describe it.
levels.example_response: 'The tall, dark castle.'
common_errors: Using two similar adjectives ('the big, large castle')
Forgetting the comma between adjectives

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using expanded noun phrases in own writing to add detail and interest, choosing adjectives for precision.
levels.example_task: Write a description of a forest. Use at least three expanded noun phrases.
levels.example_response: 'Tall, ancient trees stretched up to the sky. A narrow, winding path led deep into the forest. Bright, colourful birds sang in the branches.'
common_errors: Using generic adjectives ('nice', 'good', 'big') rather than precise ones
Expanding every noun phrase, making the writing feel overloaded

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Choosing expanded noun phrases deliberately to create a specific mood or impression, explaining the effect of adjective choices.
levels.example_task: Write two descriptions of the same house — one to make it sound welcoming and one to make it sound frightening. Use expanded noun phrases to create the mood.
levels.example_response: Welcoming: 'A cosy, red-brick cottage with a bright, cheerful garden.' Frightening: 'A crumbling, grey ruin with a dark, overgrown garden.'
common_errors: Using the same adjectives for both moods
Creating different moods but not being able to explain which adjectives contribute to the effect

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using the present tense to describe what is happening now, with oral practice.
levels.example_task: Tell me what is happening in this picture. Use 'is' or 'are': 'The boy ___ running.'
levels.example_response: 'The boy is running.'
common_errors: Using past tense ('The boy was running') when the picture shows current action
Omitting the auxiliary verb ('The boy running')

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using regular past tense -ed forms in recounts and narratives.
levels.example_task: Write about what you did yesterday. Use the past tense for each sentence.
levels.example_response: 'Yesterday I walked to school. I played with my friend. We painted pictures in art.'
common_errors: Switching between past and present tense in the same piece
Over-generalising -ed to irregular verbs: 'I goed', 'I runned'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using present and past tense consistently and correctly, including common irregular past tense forms.
levels.example_task: Rewrite these sentences in the past tense: 'I go to the park. I see a dog. It runs to me. I am happy.'
levels.example_response: 'I went to the park. I saw a dog. It ran to me. I was happy.'
common_errors: Using 'goed' instead of 'went' or 'seed' instead of 'saw'
Correctly converting some verbs but not others

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Maintaining consistent tense throughout an extended piece and explaining why tense shifts should be deliberate.
levels.example_task: Read this passage and find where the tense changes by mistake. Fix it. Why is it important to keep the tense the same?
levels.example_response: Identifies the accidental tense shift, corrects it, and explains: 'If you change tense in the middle, the reader gets confused about when things are happening. A recount should stay in the past tense.'
common_errors: Identifying obvious tense shifts but missing subtle ones
Fixing the shift but not explaining why consistency matters

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising the -ing form in sentences describing actions happening right now.
levels.example_task: Which sentence tells you something is happening right now? 'She ran.' or 'She is running.'
levels.example_response: 'She is running' — because it says "is running", that means it's happening now.
common_errors: Not hearing the difference between 'ran' (past) and 'is running' (present progressive)
Choosing 'She ran' because running happened

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the present progressive (is/are + -ing) to describe ongoing actions.
levels.example_task: Describe what the children in this picture are doing right now. Use 'is' or 'are' with an -ing word.
levels.example_response: 'The girl is painting. Two boys are playing football. The teacher is reading a book.'
common_errors: Omitting the auxiliary verb: 'The girl painting' instead of 'The girl is painting'
Using simple present instead: 'The girl paints'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using both present and past progressive forms correctly, understanding the difference from simple tenses.
levels.example_task: Write two sentences: one using the past progressive (was/were + -ing) and one using the present progressive (is/are + -ing).
levels.example_response: 'The children were singing a song when the bell rang.' 'Right now, the children are eating their lunch.'
common_errors: Confusing 'was' and 'were' in past progressive (e.g., 'they was running')
Not understanding that progressive describes an ongoing action, not a completed one

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the difference in meaning between simple and progressive forms and choosing deliberately between them in writing.
levels.example_task: What is the difference between 'I eat breakfast' and 'I am eating breakfast'? When would you use each one?
levels.example_response: '"I eat breakfast" means I do it regularly, every day — it's a habit. "I am eating breakfast" means I'm doing it right now, at this moment. You'd use the first in a routine description and the second to describe what's happening now.'
common_errors: Seeing both as meaning the same thing
Understanding the difference in context but unable to articulate the rule

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Joining two ideas using 'because' to give a reason, with oral practice.
levels.example_task: Finish this sentence: 'I wore my coat because ___.'
levels.example_response: 'I wore my coat because it was cold.'
common_errors: Giving a reason that doesn't logically follow ('I wore my coat because I like cats')
Repeating the first part instead of adding a reason

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using 'when', 'if', 'that' and 'because' to join a main clause and subordinate clause in writing.
levels.example_task: Write a sentence using 'when': 'When ___, I ___.'
levels.example_response: 'When it rains, I wear my wellies.'
common_errors: Writing the subordinate clause as a complete sentence: 'Because it was raining.' (fragment)
Using the conjunction but not completing the sentence

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using subordination with 'when', 'if', 'that' and 'because' accurately in writing, varying the position of the subordinate clause.
levels.example_task: Write two sentences about bedtime, one starting with 'if' and one ending with 'when'.
levels.example_response: 'If I finish my book, I can stay up late.' 'I brush my teeth when it is time for bed.'
common_errors: Always putting the subordinate clause in the same position
Confusing subordination with coordination (using 'because' as if it means 'and')

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Choosing between conjunctions for precise meaning and explaining why one is better than another in context.
levels.example_task: Which is better for this context — 'if' or 'when'? 'I will take my umbrella ___ it rains.' Explain your choice.
levels.example_response: '"If it rains" means it might or might not rain — you're not sure. "When it rains" means you expect it will definitely rain. "If" is better here because you don't know yet whether it will rain.'
common_errors: Treating 'if' and 'when' as interchangeable
Choosing correctly but not being able to explain the difference in meaning

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using 'and' to join two equally important ideas in a sentence.
levels.example_task: Join these ideas: 'I like dogs.' 'I like cats.'
levels.example_response: 'I like dogs and cats.'
common_errors: Writing both as separate sentences without joining
Using 'and' at the start: 'And I like cats'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using 'and', 'but' and 'or' to join clauses, understanding the different meaning each adds.
levels.example_task: Choose the right conjunction: 'I wanted to play outside ___ it was raining.' (and/but/or)
levels.example_response: 'But' — because the rain stops you playing outside. 'But' shows a contrast.
common_errors: Choosing 'and' for every sentence regardless of meaning
Not understanding that 'but' signals contrast

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using all four coordinating conjunctions (and, but, or, so) correctly in own writing.
levels.example_task: Write four sentences, each using a different coordinating conjunction: and, but, or, so.
levels.example_response: 'I packed my bag and walked to school. I wanted pizza but they had pasta. Do you want milk or juice? It was late so we went home.'
common_errors: Using 'so' and 'because' interchangeably without understanding the difference
Starting sentences with 'but' or 'so' instead of using them to join clauses

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the difference between coordination and subordination and choosing between them for effect.
levels.example_task: What is the difference between 'I stayed inside because it rained' and 'It rained so I stayed inside'? Which puts more emphasis on the reason?
levels.example_response: '"Because it rained" explains why I stayed inside — it emphasises the reason. "It rained so I stayed inside" describes the events in order — first it rained, then I stayed inside. "Because" gives more emphasis to the reason.'
common_errors: Seeing both sentences as identical in meaning and emphasis
Not understanding that word order and conjunction choice affect emphasis

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Understanding that commas separate items when listing more than two things.
levels.example_task: Read this sentence: 'I bought apples, bananas, grapes and oranges.' Point to the commas. What do they do?
levels.example_response: Points to commas. 'They separate the different fruits in the list.'
common_errors: Not noticing the commas at all
Thinking commas are the same as full stops

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using commas to separate items in a list of three or more, with 'and' before the final item.
levels.example_task: Write a sentence listing four things you would pack for a holiday. Use commas.
levels.example_response: 'I would pack sunglasses, sun cream, a towel and my swimming costume.'
common_errors: Using 'and' between every item instead of commas
Placing commas after every item including before 'and'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using commas in lists consistently and correctly in independent writing, including lists of adjectives, nouns and verbs.
levels.example_task: Write a sentence with a list of nouns, one with a list of adjectives, and one with a list of verbs.
levels.example_response: 'We saw elephants, giraffes, zebras and monkeys.' 'The house was old, dark, dusty and cold.' 'The children ran, jumped, skipped and hopped around the playground.'
common_errors: Using commas in noun lists but forgetting them in adjective or verb lists
Placing commas randomly rather than between each item

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Understanding that commas in lists prevent ambiguity and can change meaning.
levels.example_task: What is funny about this sentence if you don't use commas correctly: 'I love cooking my family and my pets'?
levels.example_response: 'Without commas, it sounds like you love cooking your family and pets — like you're going to eat them! It should be: "I love cooking, my family and my pets." The comma shows that cooking, family and pets are three separate things I love.'
common_errors: Not seeing the ambiguity in the uncomma'd version
Understanding the joke but not connecting it to the function of commas

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying naming words (nouns) in simple sentences with picture support.
levels.example_task: Look at this picture. Point to three things you can see. Those words are called nouns.
levels.example_response: Points to dog, tree, ball. 'Dog, tree and ball are nouns.'
common_errors: Pointing to actions (running, jumping) rather than things
Not understanding that a noun is a naming word

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying nouns in sentences and distinguishing them from other word types.
levels.example_task: Underline the nouns in this sentence: 'The tall boy kicked the red ball.'
levels.example_response: Underlines 'boy' and 'ball'.
common_errors: Underlining adjectives ('tall', 'red') as well as nouns
Underlining the verb ('kicked') as a noun

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying nouns including abstract and collective nouns, and distinguishing common from proper nouns.
levels.example_task: Sort these words into common nouns and proper nouns: 'London', 'city', 'dog', 'Rover', 'Tuesday', 'day'.
levels.example_response: Common nouns: city, dog, day. Proper nouns: London, Rover, Tuesday.
common_errors: Putting 'day' as a proper noun because days of the week are capitalised
Not understanding the distinction between the general category and the specific name

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining what a noun is with examples of different types and identifying nouns that can also function as other word classes.
levels.example_task: Is the word 'play' a noun or a verb? Can it be both? Give examples.
levels.example_response: '"Play" can be both. In "I play football" it's a verb — it's an action. In "We watched a play" it's a noun — it's a thing (a performance). Some words can be different word classes depending on how they are used in the sentence.'
common_errors: Insisting a word can only be one word class
Giving examples but not explaining how the context determines the word class

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying action words (verbs) in simple sentences by performing the actions.
levels.example_task: Listen: 'The boy jumps.' Which word is the doing word? Can you do it?
levels.example_response: 'Jumps!' (Child jumps.)
common_errors: Identifying the noun ('boy') instead of the verb
Not understanding what a 'doing word' is

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying verbs in sentences including action verbs and simple state verbs.
levels.example_task: Circle the verbs: 'The cat slept on the warm mat. It was happy.'
levels.example_response: Circles 'slept' and 'was'.
common_errors: Circling only action verbs and missing 'was'
Circling adjectives like 'warm' or 'happy'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying verbs in various forms (past, present, progressive) and understanding that every sentence needs a verb.
levels.example_task: Find the verb in each sentence and say whether it is past or present tense: 'The birds are singing.' 'The wind blew hard.' 'She writes a letter.'
levels.example_response: 'Are singing' — present. 'Blew' — past. 'Writes' — present.
common_errors: Identifying only one word of a two-word verb ('singing' not 'are singing')
Confusing tense labels — calling 'blew' present because it's a familiar word

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Choosing precise verbs in own writing and explaining how verb choice affects meaning.
levels.example_task: Replace the verb 'went' in this sentence with a more precise verb: 'She went down the road.' Give three different options and explain how each changes the meaning.
levels.example_response: 'She strolled down the road' — relaxed, not in a hurry. 'She sprinted down the road' — fast, maybe in a hurry or scared. 'She crept down the road' — quietly, maybe hiding from someone.
common_errors: Giving synonyms that are equally vague (e.g., 'walked', 'moved')
Providing alternatives but not explaining the difference in meaning

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using simple adjectives to describe what they can see, touch or feel.
levels.example_task: Feel this teddy bear. Tell me two words to describe it.
levels.example_response: 'Soft and fluffy.'
common_errors: Giving a noun ('teddy') instead of an adjective
Using only one adjective

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying adjectives in sentences and adding adjectives to improve descriptions.
levels.example_task: Make this sentence more interesting by adding adjectives: 'The house had a garden.'
levels.example_response: 'The old, spooky house had a beautiful, colourful garden.'
common_errors: Adding adverbs instead of adjectives
Adding adjectives that don't create a clear picture ('the nice, good house')

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using varied and specific adjectives in own writing to create vivid descriptions.
levels.example_task: Write a description of a dragon using at least four different adjectives. Make each one add new information.
levels.example_response: 'The enormous, scaly dragon had fierce, glowing eyes and sharp, curved claws.'
common_errors: Repeating similar adjectives ('big, large, huge')
Using adjectives that tell rather than show ('scary' instead of specific details that create the feeling)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Choosing adjectives deliberately for effect and explaining how they contribute to mood or character.
levels.example_task: Describe the same room twice — once to make it sound cosy and once to make it sound creepy. Explain which adjectives create each mood.
levels.example_response: Cosy: 'warm, soft, glowing, snug'. Creepy: 'cold, dark, shadowy, bare'. 'I used warm colours and comfortable textures for cosy, and cold colours and emptiness for creepy.'
common_errors: Using obvious adjectives without subtlety
Creating the mood but not being able to explain which adjectives contribute

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Understanding that adverbs tell us how something is done, using physical demonstration.
levels.example_task: Walk slowly across the room. Now walk quickly. What words did I use to tell you HOW to walk?
levels.example_response: 'Slowly and quickly — they tell you how to walk.'
common_errors: Confusing 'slowly' with 'slow' — not distinguishing adverb from adjective
Not connecting the word to the action it describes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adding -ly adverbs to sentences to describe how an action is performed.
levels.example_task: Add an adverb to this sentence: 'The girl sang ___.'
levels.example_response: 'The girl sang beautifully.'
common_errors: Adding an adjective instead: 'The girl sang beautiful'
Using only common adverbs like 'quickly' or 'slowly' every time

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using adverbs in own writing to add detail about how, when or where actions happen.
levels.example_task: Write three sentences about a race. Use a different adverb in each one.
levels.example_response: 'The runners waited nervously at the start line. Suddenly, the whistle blew. They sprinted desperately towards the finish.'
common_errors: Using the same adverb repeatedly
Placing the adverb in an awkward position in the sentence

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Recognising that not all adverbs end in -ly and choosing adverbs deliberately for effect in writing.
levels.example_task: Name three adverbs that do not end in -ly. Use one in a sentence.
levels.example_response: 'Fast', 'well', 'soon'. 'She runs fast' — 'fast' is an adverb because it describes how she runs, even though it doesn't end in -ly.
common_errors: Insisting all adverbs must end in -ly
Confusing 'fast' the adjective ('a fast car') with 'fast' the adverb ('she runs fast')

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising that some words are made from two words joined together.
levels.example_task: The word 'football' is made from two words. What are they?
levels.example_response: 'Foot' and 'ball'.
common_errors: Breaking the word at the wrong point (e.g., 'foo' and 'tball')
Not understanding that both parts are real words

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Splitting compound words into their two parts and creating compound words by combining two words.
levels.example_task: Split these compound words: 'bedroom', 'sunflower', 'playground'. Now make a compound word from 'rain' and 'coat'.
levels.example_response: 'Bed-room, sun-flower, play-ground. Rain + coat = raincoat.'
common_errors: Splitting at the wrong point in less obvious compounds
Combining words that don't form a real compound (e.g., 'rain + hat = rainhat')

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using knowledge of compound words to read and understand unfamiliar words, and using compound words in own writing.
levels.example_task: You see the word 'thunderstorm' in a book. How does knowing it is a compound word help you read and understand it?
levels.example_response: 'I can split it into "thunder" and "storm" — two words I already know. A thunderstorm is a storm with thunder. Breaking it into parts helps me read it and understand what it means.'
common_errors: Not applying compound word knowledge as a decoding strategy
Understanding the parts but not combining their meanings

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining how compound words are formed and distinguishing genuine compounds from words that simply contain other words.
levels.example_task: Is 'carpet' a compound word? Why or why not? What about 'cupboard'?
levels.example_response: 'Carpet' is not a compound word — 'car' and 'pet' are real words but 'carpet' doesn't mean a car-pet. 'Cupboard' is a compound word — it was originally a board for keeping cups on, so both parts contribute to the meaning.
common_errors: Thinking any word that contains two smaller words is a compound
Not applying the meaning test — do both parts contribute to the whole meaning?

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using basic terms — letter, word, sentence — correctly when talking about reading and writing.
levels.example_task: Point to a letter. Point to a word. Point to a sentence.
levels.example_response: Child correctly points to a single letter, a single word, and a complete sentence.
common_errors: Confusing 'letter' with 'word' or 'word' with 'sentence'
Pointing to a word when asked for a letter

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using Year 1 terminology (singular, plural, full stop, question mark, exclamation mark) when discussing texts.
levels.example_task: What is the name of this punctuation mark: ? And this one: ! What does each one do?
levels.example_response: 'That's a question mark — it goes at the end of a question. That's an exclamation mark — it shows strong feeling.'
common_errors: Confusing the names of punctuation marks
Knowing the name but not the function

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using Year 1 and Year 2 grammatical terminology accurately (noun, verb, adjective, adverb, tense, apostrophe, comma, sentence type names).
levels.example_task: Find a noun, a verb, an adjective and an adverb in this sentence: 'The brave knight fought fiercely.'
levels.example_response: 'Knight' is a noun, 'fought' is a verb, 'brave' is an adjective, 'fiercely' is an adverb.
common_errors: Confusing adjective and adverb
Identifying the correct word but assigning the wrong term

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using grammatical terminology fluently and precisely when discussing own and others' writing, and when explaining grammar rules.
levels.example_task: Explain to your partner how to write a compound sentence. Use the correct grammatical terms.
levels.example_response: 'A compound sentence has two main clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction — that means "and", "but", "or" or "so". Each clause must have a subject and a verb. For example: "The dog barked" is one clause and "the cat ran away" is another. You join them with "and": "The dog barked and the cat ran away."'
common_errors: Using approximate language instead of precise terminology
Defining terms correctly in isolation but not applying them in context

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Beginning to hear the difference between standard and non-standard forms in common phrases.
levels.example_task: Which sounds right for a story: 'We was playing' or 'We were playing'?
levels.example_response: 'We were playing.'
common_errors: Choosing the non-standard form because it matches their spoken dialect
Not hearing any difference between the two forms

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using standard verb forms in writing for common non-standard patterns (was/were, did/done, went/gone).
levels.example_task: Write the correct form: 'I ___ my homework.' (did/done)
levels.example_response: 'I did my homework.'
common_errors: Writing 'I done my homework' because this is the spoken form
Correctly choosing in a test but reverting to non-standard in free writing

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using Standard English consistently in writing, including subject-verb agreement and standard verb forms.
levels.example_task: Write a short paragraph about a school trip using Standard English. Check that your verbs are correct.
levels.example_response: Child writes with consistent standard forms: 'we were', 'they went', 'she saw', 'I did'.
common_errors: Mixing standard and non-standard forms in the same piece
Using standard forms for common verbs but non-standard for less frequent ones

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the difference between Standard English and dialect, understanding when each is appropriate.
levels.example_task: Your character in a story speaks in dialect: 'I ain't going nowhere.' Rewrite in Standard English. When would a character speak in dialect and when in Standard English?
levels.example_response: Standard English: 'I'm not going anywhere.' 'A character might speak in dialect when talking informally to friends — it shows their personality and where they come from. They would use Standard English in a formal letter or speaking to someone important.'
common_errors: Thinking dialect is always 'wrong' rather than appropriate in certain contexts
Converting the dialect but not being able to explain when each register is appropriate
